title: Bastion Classification of Lower Limb Blast Injuries
description: Stratifies lower limb blast injuries to guide treatment. Developed by military surgeons at Camp Bastion, Afghanistan, to classify explosion-related lower extremity injuries and correlate with treatment needs.

options.label: Injury involving lower leg permitting effective below-knee tourniquet application
Injury involving proximal lower leg or thigh, permitting effective above-knee tourniquet application
Proximal thigh injury, preventing effective tourniquet application

parameters.name: segmental_injury
parameters.description: Presence of potentially viable tissue distal to the most proximal injury

classes.management: Local hemorrhage control, consider foot salvage vs. amputation
Below-knee tourniquet effective for hemorrhage control

classes.description: Injury involving proximal lower leg or thigh
classes.management: Above-knee tourniquet effective for hemorrhage control (most common pattern: 49%)
Tourniquet application challenging, may require proximal vascular control
Tourniquet ineffective, requires operative proximal vascular control

suffixes.meaning: Segmental injury - potentially viable tissue distal to injury

references: Jacobs N, Rourke K, Rutherford J, Hicks A, Smith SR, Templeton P, et al. Lower limb injuries caused by improvised explosive devices: Proposed 'Bastion Classification' and prospective validation. Injury. 2014 Sep;45(9):1422-8.

Lundy JB, Hobbs CM. 'Bastion Classification': evolution of experience mandates caution when considering using class as predictor for method of temporary vascular control. Injury. 2013 Nov;44(11):1671-2.
Scerbo MH, Mumm JP, Gates K, Love JD, Wade CE, Holcomb JB, et al. Safety and Appropriateness of Tourniquets in 105 Civilians. Prehosp Emerg Care. 2016 Nov-Dec;20(6):712-722.
formula: Classification = Class (1-5) + Applicable suffixes (S, A, B, C, D)
notes: Developed at Camp Bastion, Afghanistan during Operation Herrick 13
69% of injuries in validation study were traumatic amputations
49% of casualties suffered bilateral lower limb amputation
Classes 4 and 5 (preventing effective tourniquet) accounted for 18% of injuries
Not designed to correlate with mortality, transfusion requirements, or definitive amputation level
Patients without prehospital tourniquets had increased transfusion needs and mortality from hemorrhagic shock
